revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian |name = Drew Carey |caption = Carey at a [[Mercy for Animals]] charity event on September 12, 2014 |image = Drew Carey 2014.jpg |birth_name = Drew Allison Carey |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|5|23}} |birth_place = [[Cleveland]], Ohio, U.S. |party = [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] |medium = [[Stand-up]], [[television]], [[film]] |genre = [[Improvisational comedy]] |notable_work = ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]''
''[[Drew Carey's Green Screen Show]]''
'''Host of''':
''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]''
''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]''
''[[Power of 10 (U.S. game show)|Power of 10]]''
''[[Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza]]'' |active = 1985–present |module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{flag|United States}} | branch = {{flag|United States Marine Corps|23px}} | unit = [[United States Marine Corps Reserve]] | rank = [[Sergeant#United States Marine Corps|Sergeant]] | serviceyears = 1981–1987 }} }} ''' Drew Allison Carey'''{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/DrewFromTV/status/743201079085539328|title=Drew Carey on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-06-15}} (born May 23, 1958) is an American actor, comedian, sports executive, and [[game show host]]. After serving in the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]] and making a name for himself in [[stand-up comedy]], Carey eventually gained popularity starring in his own [[Situation comedy|sitcom]], ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'', and serving as host of the U.S. version of the improv comedy show [[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'']], both of which aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. Drew Carey has appeared in several films, television series, music videos, a made-for-television film, and a computer game. He has hosted the [[game show]] ''[[The Price Is Right (U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]]'' since 2007 on [[CBS]]. He is interested in a variety of sports and has worked as a photographer at [[United States men's national soccer team|U.S. National Team soccer games]]. He is a minority owner of the [[Major League Soccer]] team [[Seattle Sounders FC]]. Carey has written an autobiography, ''[[Dirty Jokes and Beer|Dirty Jokes and Beer: Stories of the Unrefined]]'', detailing his early life and television career. ==Early life== [[File:Drew Carey-Marines.jpg|alt=Head shot of a young, blond Carey dressed in military fatigues.|thumb|upright|Carey in his [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]] uniform, with [[United States Marine Corps rank insignia|rank insignia]] of a [[Corporal#United States Marine Corps|Corporal]]]] Carey is the youngest of Lewis and Beulah Carey's three sons and raised in the [[Old Brooklyn]] neighborhood of [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]].{{Cite news |title=Drew Carey: The Times of His Life |publisher=Cleveland.com |url=http://www.cleveland.com/homegrown/index.ssf?/tv/more/drew/time.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E4OeE3k?url=http://www.cleveland.com/homegrown/index.ssf?%2Ftv%2Fmore%2Fdrew%2Ftime.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} When Drew was eight years old, his father died from a [[brain tumor]].{{cite web |last=Buchanan |first=Jason |title=Drew Carey Film Biography |publisher=[[Allrovi]] |url=http://www.allrovi.com/name/drew-carey-mn0000804257 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E4lIv72?url=http://www.allrovi.com/name/drew-carey-mn0000804257 |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news|last=Zaslow|first=Jeffery|title=Strong opinions|work=[[USA Weekend]]|url=http://www.usaweekend.com/00_issues/000507/000507drew_carey.html|pages=8–9|date=May 5, 2000}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=Red Director |fix-attempted=yes }} He played the cornet and trumpet in the marching band of [[James Ford Rhodes High School]], from which he graduated in 1975.{{Cite book|last=Carey|first=Drew|title=Dirty Jokes and Beer: Stories of the Unrefined|publisher=Hyperion|year=1997|location=New York|isbn=0-7868-8939-X}} He continued on to college at [[Kent State University]] (KSU) and was a part of Delta Tau Delta Fraternity. He was expelled twice for poor academic performance. He left KSU after three years. After leaving the university, Carey enlisted into the [[United States Marine Corps Reserve]] in 1981 and served for six years. He moved to [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] for a few months in 1983, and for a short time worked as a [[bank teller]] and a waiter at [[Denny's]]. ==Stand-up career== In 1985, he began his comedy career by following up on a suggestion by [[David H. Lawrence XVII|David Lawrence]] (a disc jockey friend who had been paying Drew to write jokes for David's radio show in Cleveland) to go to the library and borrow books on how to write jokes.{{Cite news |last=Mervis |first=Scott |title=Comedy Preview: Drew Carey rocks! |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/20020927drew3.asp |date=September 27, 2002 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E4zTLu9?url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/20020927drew3.asp |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news|last=Johnson|first=Dean|title=Bookish comic is a quick study|work=[[Boston Herald]]|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/68242241.html?dids=68242241:68242241&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+10%2C+1994&author=Dean+Johnson&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=COMEDY+Bookish+comic+is+a+quick+study&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=June 10, 1994|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} The following year, after winning an open-microphone contest, he became [[Master of Ceremonies]] at the Cleveland Comedy Club. He performed at comedy clubs over the next few years in Cleveland and Los Angeles. He first came to the national eye as a comedian when he competed in the 1988 ''[[Star Search]]''.{{Cite news|title=Sitcoms are a burden to Carey|work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ST&s_site=dfw&p_multi=ST&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF8F5FC2D047F9&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|date=January 18, 1994|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} Carey was working as a stand-up comedian when he appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' in November 1991.{{Cite news|last=Hansen|first=Liane|title=Drew Carey Made Johnny Carson Laugh So Hard He Cried (Transcript)|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NR&d_origin=transcripts&z=NR&p_theme=nr&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F5742274B44C984&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|date=January 7, 1996|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} His performance that night impressed Carson, who invited Carey to the couch next to his desk; this was considered a rare honor for any comedian.{{Cite news |last=Smokler |first=Kevin |title=This Comic's Life Is Not Always A Laughing Matter |work=The Gazette |url=http://www.jhu.edu/~gazette/aprjun96/apr2996/drew.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E5IrnzC?url=http://www.jhu.edu/~gazette/aprjun96/apr2996/drew.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In that same year, Carey joined the ''14th Annual Young Comedians Special'' on [[HBO]] and made his first appearance on ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]''.{{cite web|title=Drew Carey Biography|work=[[Comedy Central]]|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/comedians/browse/c/drew_carey.jhtml|accessdate=April 15, 2009|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080613123749/http://www.comedycentral.com/comedians/browse/c/drew_carey.jhtml |archivedate = June 13, 2008|deadurl=yes}} In 1994, Carey wrote his own stand-up comedy special, ''Drew Carey: Human Cartoon'', which aired on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] and won a [[CableACE Award]] for Best Writing.{{Cite news|last=Bobbin|first=Jay|title=Drew Carey Presides Over 18th CableACE Awards on TNT|work=[[The Buffalo News]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BN&p_theme=bn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF999D976DE0D6&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|registration=yes|date=November 10, 1996|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} ==Acting career== ===Early roles=== His early stand-up career led to supporting roles on television shows, during which he developed the character of a hapless middle-class bachelor. In 1993, Carey had a small role in the film ''[[Coneheads]]'' as a taxi passenger. In 1994, Carey co-starred with [[John Caponera]] in ''[[The Good Life (1994 TV series)|The Good Life]]'', a short-lived [[Situation comedy|sitcom]] on [[NBC]].{{Cite news|last=Bickelhaupt|first=Susan|title=Drew Carey's 'Good Life'|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BG&p_theme=bg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADE0BE65C28420&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|registration=yes|date=March 15, 1994|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} After the show was cancelled, [[Bruce Helford]], a writer on the show, hired Carey as a consultant for the television show ''Someone Like Me''.{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Allan |title=Drew Carey Succeeds By Being Himself |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-11-16/news/9711160210_1_drew-carey-show-character-working |date=November 16, 1997 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E5RNF28?url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-11-16/news/9711160210_1_drew-carey-show-character-working |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===''The Drew Carey Show''=== After their stint on ''Someone Like Me'', Carey and Helford developed and produced the storyline for ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]''. The sitcom revolved around a fictionalized version of Carey, as he took on the stresses of life and work with his group of childhood friends. The show premiered on September 13, 1995, on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. In his autobiography, Carey revealed his frustration with having to deal with [[censorship|censors]] and being unable to employ the [[off-color humor]] common in his stand-up routines. Carey initially earned $60,000 per episode in the first seasons, then renegotiated for $300,000.{{Cite news |last=Huff |first=Richard |title=Drew to Carey on with Sitcom & Laugh All the Way to the Bank |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1998/02/27/1998-02-27_drew_to_carey_on_with_sitcom.html |date=February 27, 1998 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E5VFktv?url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/1998-02-27/entertainment/18067265_1_drew-carey-show-wb-network-morning-america |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} By the final season, he was earning $750,000 per episode.{{Cite news |author=[[Associated Press]] |title=Drew Carey going out with a whisper |work=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-03-carey-going-off-air_x.htm |date=May 3, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E5erF1f?url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-03-carey-going-off-air_x.htm |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The show had high ratings for its first few seasons, but declining ratings and increasing production costs (around $3 million per episode) precipitated its cancellation.{{cite news |last=Gillespie |first=Nick |author2=Steve Kurtz |title=Stand-Up Guy |work=[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]] |url=http://reason.com/archives/1997/11/01/stand-up-guy |date=November 1997 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Fw91hGn?url=http://reason.com/archives/1997/11/01/stand-up-guy |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The program had a total of 233 episodes over its nine-year run, and Carey was one of four actors to appear in every episode. ===Improv television=== While still starring in ''The Drew Carey Show'', Carey began hosting the American version of the [[improvisational theatre|improvisational comedy]] show ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (U.S. TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'' in 1998. He would announce the improv guests, direct the games, and then would usually involve himself in the final game of the episode. The show ran for a total of 220 episodes until the show's cancellation in 2006. In 1998, the [[New York Friars' Club]] made Carey the newest inductee of the group's [[Comedy Central Roast]]. His friend [[Ryan Stiles]] (who costarred in ''The Drew Carey Show'' and ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'') served as the roastmaster.{{Cite news |last=Siano |first=Joseph |title=Now Roasting (and Toasting) Drew Carey |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/tv/signoff-now-roasting-and-toasting-drew-carey.html |date=October 25, 1998 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E5x8BXm?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/tv/signoff-now-roasting-and-toasting-drew-carey.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Carey's income from ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' and ''The Drew Carey Show'' led to his inclusion on the ''[[Forbes]]'' list of highest-paid entertainers of 1998, at 24th with $45.5 million.{{Cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |title=Hometown hero comes back to Cleveland |work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]] |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/091799/ent_0917990034.shtml |date=September 17, 1999 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E5zUrfr?url=http://lubbockonline.com/stories/091799/ent_0917990034.shtml |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} For [[The WB Television Network|the WB's]] 2004–2005 [[prime time]] schedule, Carey co-produced and starred in ''[[Drew Carey's Green Screen Show]]'', a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?''.{{Cite news |last=Bianculli |first=David |title='Green' Can't Be Improv-ed On |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2004/10/07/2004-10-07__green__can_t_be_improv-ed_on.html |date=October 7, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E66sIRv?url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/2004/10/07/2004-10-07__green__can_t_be_improv-ed_on.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} It was canceled by the WB, but picked up shortly afterward by Comedy Central.{{Cite news |last=MacDonald |first=Patrick |title=Drew Carey, funny friends open Seattle Comedy Festival |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2002561779_improv15.html |date=October 15, 2005 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E689MzF?url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2002561779_improv15.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The show's premise relied on the use of a [[green screen]] for all of the actors' improv interactions. Animation on the screen was inserted during post-production. In April 2011, Carey began hosting a primetime improv show, called ''[[Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza]]''. It was filmed at the [[MGM Grand Las Vegas|MGM Grand]] in Las Vegas, Nevada, and first aired on April 11.{{cite news |last=Wedel |first=Mark |title=They find freedom in live shows: 'Whose Line' vet Ryan Stiles talks tiger blood, psychic links and why no one likes Drew Carey |work=[[Kalamazoo Gazette]] |url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/kalamazoo/index.ssf/2011/06/they_find_freedom_in_live_show.html |date=June 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E6ZDMJN?url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/kalamazoo/index.ssf/2011/06/they_find_freedom_in_live_show.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The show took on the premise of ''Whose Line?'' and ''Drew Carey's Green Screen Show'' in that it features many of the same performers from both shows and did improv based on audience-provided suggestions. ===Improv All-Stars=== Carey was one of the founders of the Improv All-Stars, a group of eleven actors who perform in unscripted skits.{{cite news |last=Kraisirideja |first=Sandra |title='Whose Line' co-star relishing 'Improv All-Stars' tour |url=http://www.nctimes.com/entertainment/art-and-theater/theater/article_40560dfb-1251-5fe1-ab75-70c2354f59ae.html |work=[[North County Times]] |date=October 27, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E70rDWn?url=http://www.nctimes.com/entertainment/art-and-theater/theater/article_40560dfb-1251-5fe1-ab75-70c2354f59ae.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The group joined Carey in all three of his improv shows, ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'', ''Drew Carey's Green Screen Show'', and ''Drew Carey's Improv-A-Ganza'', and some members had major roles or guest-starred on ''The Drew Carey Show''.{{Cite news|last=Swift|first=Orla|title='Drew Carey' improv keeps the cast united|work=[[The News & Observer]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=RLOB&p_theme=rlob&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=%28Drew%20Carey%20improv%20keeps%20the%20cast%20united%29&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28Drew%20Carey%20improv%20keeps%20the%20cast%20united%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no|date=November 9, 2005|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} The Improv All-Stars travel on comedy tours, performing at comedy clubs throughout the United States. ==Game show host== ===''Power of 10''=== Beginning in 2007, Carey began hosting [[game show]]s, beginning with his April selection as host of the [[CBS]] game show pilot ''[[Power of 10 (U.S. game show)|Power of 10]]''. The show ran from August 7, 2007 to January 23, 2008 and aired twice weekly during the late summer and early fall. Each game featured contestants predicting how a cross-section of Americans responded to questions covering a wide variety of topics in polls conducted by CBS.{{Cite news|last=Hale |first=Mike |title=Drew Carey's "Power of 10" draws on his persona |work=[[The Denver Post]] |url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_6633628?source=bb |date=August 17, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710012107/http://www.denverpost.com/ci_6633628?source=bb |archivedate=July 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===''The Price Is Right''=== After taping the [[pilot episode]] for ''Power of 10'', Carey was contacted by CBS about replacing [[Bob Barker]]—who had earlier announced his own retirement—as host of ''[[The Price Is Right]]''. After initially turning down the offer, Carey announced on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' that he would succeed Barker as host of the program beginning in the fall of 2007.{{Cite news |last=Bauder |first=David |publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] |title='Price Is Right' for Drew Carey |url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2007Jul23/0,4675,TVPriceCarey,00.html |date=July 23, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E7JxXgX?url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2007Jul23/0,4675,TVPriceCarey,00.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} His first episode of ''The Price Is Right'' was taped on August 15, 2007, and his shows began airing on October 15, 2007. In response to replacing Barker as host of the game show, Carey stated "You can't replace Bob Barker. I don't compare myself to anybody... It's only about what you're doing and supposed to do, and I feel like I'm supposed to be doing this."{{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |title=Drew Carey Finds Ms. Right |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/10/10/entertainment/main3354021.shtml |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=October 12, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E7O9FmS?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/10/10/entertainment/main3354021.shtml |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} When Carey began hosting, the set, theme music, and show logo were updated. However, Carey kept the old closing line about [[Neutering|spaying and neutering]] the pets that originated with Barker, although his version uses slightly different wording. During Carey's second year as host, he began to write some of the sketches used during the [[The Showcase|Showcase]], which sometimes features guest appearances by stars of other CBS programs. In the April Fools' Day 2013 episode, Carey and announcer [[George Gray (TV host)|George Gray]] switched places with the models, letting the two men be the models for the episode. On the April Fools' Day 2014 episode, Carey and Gray traded positions with [[Craig Ferguson]] (who was hosting ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson|The Late Late Show]]'' at the time) and [[Shadoe Stevens]], reprising their respective roles on Ferguson's show while Ferguson hosted and Stevens announced on ''Price''. On the first week of Season 46 (September 18-22, 2017), Carey celebrated his 10 years as host of the show, joining Barker as the only two to have hosted for at least a decade. ==Other roles and appearances== [[File:DrewCareySD.jpg|alt=Larger than life figure of Carey's head and shoulders, posted above the studio entrance.|thumb|Entrance to ''[[Sounds Dangerous!]]'' at [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]]]] Carey began appearing in commercials for restaurants in the late 1990s in Canada with [[The Great Root Bear]], but his two-year contract with [[A&W (Canada)|A&W Food Services of Canada]] was cut short in November 1998 after [[The High Road to China|an episode]] of ''The Drew Carey Show'' featured [[McDonald's]]. As a result of his dismissal, Carey sued A&W for compensation.{{Cite news|last=House|first=Rick|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|title=TV Funnyman is Fried About Fast-Food Fight|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SR&p_theme=sr&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF48A8CA14CBF8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|date=January 14, 1999|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] (then "Disney-MGM Studios"), part of [[Walt Disney World Resort]] in [[Florida]], debuted a 12-minute attraction in 1999 titled ''[[Sounds Dangerous!]]''.{{cite web |title=Sounds Dangerous – Starring Drew Carey |publisher=[[Walt Disney World]] |url=http://disneyworld.disney.go.com/wdw/parks/attractionDetail?id=SoundsDangerousStarringDrewCareyAttractionPage&bhcp=1 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E7VXE7G?url=http://disneyworld.disney.go.com/parks/hollywood-studios/attractions/sounds-dangerous-starring-drew-carey/ |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In the show, a camera follows Carey through a day as an undercover detective. When his video camera fails, the audience is left in complete darkness, wearing earphones, following his adventure through sound cues. The attraction is now closed. Also in 1999, Carey appeared in [["Weird Al" Yankovic]]'s music video for his song [[It's All About the Pentiums|"It's All About The Pentiums".]] In 2000, Carey was given a cameo appearance in the ''[[The Sims: House Party|House Party]]'' expansion pack of the computer game ''[[The Sims]]''.{{Cite news|last=Gaudiosi |first=John |title=Sims rocks in Drew Carey |work=Video Business |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-10997382_ITM |registration=yes |date=March 19, 2001 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709035316/http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-10997382_ITM |archivedate=July 9, 2009 |deadurl=yes }} To make him appear, the characters in the game must throw a successful party, which causes Carey to arrive in a limo and join the festivities. Carey is a fan of ''The Sims'' series, and during one April Fool's episode of ''The Drew Carey Show'', a scene takes place completely within ''The Sims''.{{Cite news|last=Frisinger|first=Cathy|title=The Sims It's fun. It's addictive. It puts you in control of a simulated family. But is the sims really a good computer-game choice for your child?|work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ST&s_site=dfw&p_multi=ST&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EEE9EC1E1FAC202&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|registration=yes|date=October 2, 2001|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} Carey made several other cameo appearances in [[music video]]s, including [["Weird Al" Yankovic]]'s "[[It's All About the Pentiums]]"{{Cite news |publisher=MTV |title="Weird Al" Enlists Drew Carey For New Video |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1435280/19990804/yankovic_weird_al.jhtml |date=August 4, 1999 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E7dlvH5?url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1435280/.jhtml |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and [[Fountains of Wayne]]'s 2004 video for "Mexican Wine", giving an introduction to the video as if it were on a stage.{{Cite news|last=Mervis|first=Scott|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|title=A Gush of Power Pop|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PG&p_theme=pg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10403BD4F37A57F4&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|date=July 23, 2004|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} On January 21, 2001, Drew entered as [[Vince McMahon]]'s guest entrant in the [[Royal Rumble]] match. Although primarily known for his television work, Carey has done limited film work, with his first appearance in 1993's ''Coneheads''. His next film was the 2000 [[television film]] ''[[Geppetto (TV musical)|Geppetto]]'', which debuted on [[Walt Disney anthology television series|''The Wonderful World of Disney'']]. The film, an adaptation of ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'', included actor [[Wayne Brady]], who had joined Carey on his improv shows.{{Cite news |first=Anita |last=Gates |work=[[The New York Times]] |title=Geppetto (2000) |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/198497/Geppetto/overview |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E7ixrrJ?url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/198497/Geppetto/overview |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Carey took singing lessons to prepare for the role. In 2005, Carey appeared in three films: the animated film ''[[Robots (2005 film)|Robots]]'', where he provided a voice-over for the character [[List of Robots characters#Crank|Crank]]; ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]'', where he retold a dirty joke along with other celebrities; and the documentary ''[[Fuck (film)|Fuck]]'', where he was interviewed. Carey provided the entertainment for the 2002 Annual [[White House]] correspondents' dinner. Once Carey completed his stand-up routine for the 1,800 guests, President [[George W. Bush]], noting Carey's improv work, made a joke of his own: "Drew? Got any interest in the Middle East?"{{Cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |title=President Jokes With Drew Carey, Ozzy Osbourne at White House Awards Dinner |publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,52023,00.html |date=May 6, 2002 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E7sXGUh?url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,52023,00.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2003, he joined [[Jamie Kennedy]] to host the WB's live special ''[[Play for a Billion]]''.{{Cite news|last=Deggans|first=Eric|work=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|title=Pepsi television pitch lies in chimp's hands|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/09/13/Business/Pepsi_television_pitc.shtml|date=September 13, 2003|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} In September 2003, Carey led a group of comedians, including [[Blake Clark]] and ''The Drew Carey Show'''s [[Kathy Kinney]], on a comedy tour of Iraq.{{Cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] |title=Drew Carey Performs at Base in Iraq |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,98547,00.html |date=September 29, 2003 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E81u1Xe?url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,98547,00.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On June 8, 2006, ''Drew Carey's Sporting Adventures'' debuted on the [[Travel Channel]]. In this series, Carey traveled throughout Germany to photograph multiple [[FIFA World Cup]] [[Football (soccer)|soccer]] games while he immerses himself in the culture of the towns and states he visits.{{Cite news |last=Whitehead |first=Johnnie |title=Carey on the road (with lens in tow) for U.S. team |work=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/worldcup/2006-06-08-drew-carey_x.htm |date=June 8, 2006 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E84plwq?url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/worldcup/2006-06-08-drew-carey_x.htm |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In early 2008, Carey appeared in [[Matt Groening]]'s ''[[The Simpsons]]'' as part of the [[List of The Simpsons episodes|episode]] "[[All About Lisa]]" as a guest on the ''[[Krusty the Clown Show]]''. He also surfaced in the second season of ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'', playing a well-liked former boss to Jeff Winger. On March 4, 2014, it was announced on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' that Carey would compete on the [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 18)|season 18]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]''. He was partnered with professional dancer [[Cheryl Burke]]. The couple was eliminated on the sixth week of competition, finishing in 8th place. On the last Friday of every month, he hosts a three-hour radio show on Little Steven's Underground Garage entitled, "Drew Carey's Friday Night Dance Party." [[SiriusXM]]. On March 6, 2018, Carey appeared in an episode of ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'' as a retired Marine. His character was a sergeant, the last rank he held in real life; real pictures of him in dress blues and everyday garb were on the plasma screen in the squadroom. ==Writing== Carey has routinely written throughout his career, including developing his stand-up comedy routines in his early stand-up career, and then moving on to assist in writing sitcoms. In 1997, Carey published his [[autobiography]], ''[[Dirty Jokes and Beer: Stories of the Unrefined]]'', wherein he shared memories of his early childhood and of his father's death when he was eight. He also revealed that he was once [[child sexual abuse|molested]], had suffered bouts of [[depression (mood)|depression]], and had made two [[suicide]] attempts by swallowing a large amount of sleeping pills. The book discusses his [[Fraternities and sororities|college fraternity]] years while attending Kent State University and his professional career up to that time. The book featured large amounts of profanity and, as the title suggests, includes multiple dirty jokes (there is one at the start of each chapter) and references to beer, which was a departure from his on-screen persona. The book was featured on ''The New York Times'' bestseller list for three months.{{cite web|work=ABC.com|title=Personnel Files-Drew Carey|url=http://abc.go.com/primetime/drewcarey/bios/drew_carey.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060426200850/http://abc.go.com/primetime/drewcarey/bios/drew_carey.html|archivedate=April 26, 2006}} ==Personal life== He adopted his [[crew cut]] hairstyle while serving in the [[United States Marine Corps]]. Carey has had [[refractive surgery]] to correct his vision and therefore did not really require glasses (any glasses he wore in public were merely props to help the audience recognize him).{{Cite news|last=Clark|first=Doug|title=Operation Deserves Second Look|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SR&p_theme=sr&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF44D9DBF00F2F&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|registration=yes|date=January 23, 2001|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} However, while this was true for several years, on the May 17, 2006, episode of ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' he revealed that when he turned 40, he actually developed a need for bifocals. As of 2007, Carey resides in Los Angeles and New York City.{{Cite news|title=Carey puts little value in "Price" rumors|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|url=http://www.dailynews.com/ci_6350371?source=most_viewed|date=July 11, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101153658/http://www.dailynews.com/ci_6350371?source=most_viewed|archivedate=January 1, 2008}} Carey is a father figure to Nicole Jaracz' son, Connor, from a previous relationship; they have no children together. Nicole and Connor have appeared alongside Carey on ''The Price Is Right'' several times. Although he proposed to Jaracz in 2007, the pair did not wed, as the engagement was called off in January 2012.{{Cite news |author=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] |title=Drew Carey Engaged to Cooking School Grad |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,301372,00.html |date=October 12, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E8KeJU0?url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,301372,00.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|date=January 26, 2012|title=Drew Carey & Fiancée Nicole Jaracz Call Off Engagement|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20564948,00.html}} Carey announced his engagement to therapist Amie Harwick in January 2018.{{cite web|url=http://people.com/tv/drew-carey-is-engaged-amie-harwick/|title=The Price Is Right's Drew Carey Is Engaged to Dr. Amie Harwick!|last=Strohm|first=Emily|last2=Stone|first2=Natalie|date=January 31, 2018|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} After suffering chest pains while filming ''The Drew Carey Show'' in August 2001, Carey went to the hospital, where he underwent a coronary [[angioplasty]].{{cite news |last=Huff |first=Richard |work=[[New York Daily News]] |title=Show To 'Carey' On Without Ailing Star |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2001-08-14/entertainment/18363390_1_drew-carey-show-chest-pains-show-s-writers |date=August 14, 2001 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E8dqhJO?url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2001-08-14/entertainment/18363390_1_drew-carey-show-chest-pains-show-s-writers |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Although his weight was a comedic topic throughout his sitcom and improv shows, in 2010, he began a diet and exercise plan, resulting in an extensive weight loss. He also claimed that he had cured his Type 2 diabetes as a direct result.{{cite news |last=Hunter |first=Aina |title=Drew Carey Weight Loss (Picture): Did He Really Shed Diabetes along with Fat? |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504763_162-20017007-10391704.html |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=September 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E9CnJvc?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504763_162-20017007-10391704.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Carey is a [[Buddhism|Buddhist]].{{cite episode |title=Drew Carey/Claire Foy & Matt Smith/Sebastian Maniscalco/Aimee Mann |series=The Late Show with Stephen Colbert |series-link=The Late Show with Stephen Colbert |network=CBS |station=WCCO-TV |date=October 28, 2016 |season=2 |number=34}} ===Political views=== Carey is an outspoken [[Libertarian Party (United States)|libertarian]].{{Cite news |last=Harnden |first=Toby |author2=Alex Spillius |author3=Tim Shipman |author4=Amanda Halligan |author5=Jessica Jerrell |publisher=[[Telegraph.co.uk]] |title=The most influential US conservatives: 21–40 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1435462/The-most-influential-US-conservatives-21-40.html |date=April 24, 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E9QJPMa?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1435462/The-most-influential-US-conservatives-21-40.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news|last=Miller |first=John J. |work=[[National Review]] |title=Right-leaning celebrity alert! Watch the comedian Drew Carey |url=http://nrd.nationalreview.com/article/?q=M2VmZTRmZGFmZmExNTFiMTM1ZDJmN2UwY2Y0NDYwOWI |date=October 22, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001160723/http://nrd.nationalreview.com/article/?q=M2VmZTRmZGFmZmExNTFiMTM1ZDJmN2UwY2Y0NDYwOWI%3D |archivedate=October 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news |publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] |title=GOP in Hollywood: Endangered Species? |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,132225,00.html |date=September 13, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E9iPr7l?url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,132225,00.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite news |last=Oldenburg |first=Ann |work=[[USA Today]] |title=Candidates both good for a laugh |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-03-08-white-house-humor_x.htm |date=March 8, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E9mHtsj?url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-03-08-white-house-humor_x.htm |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He has expressed his political philosophy in the following terms: "I believe the answers to all the problems we face as a society won't come from Washington, it will come from us. So the way we decide to live our lives and our decisions about what we buy or don't buy are much more important than who we vote for."{{cite news |last=Young |first=Cathy |date=October 29, 2008 |title=Who's Getting Your Vote? |work=[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]] |url=http://reason.com/archives/2008/10/29/whos-getting-your-vote/singlepage |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60E9wBnLE?url=http://reason.com/archives/2008/10/29/whos-getting-your-vote/singlepage |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Carey expressed his distaste for the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]]'s management of the [[War in Iraq|Iraq War]], specifically on the September 14, 2007, episode of ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]''. He made donations to [[Ron Paul]]'s presidential campaign for the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 election]].{{cite news|title=Fundrace|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|url=http://fundrace.huffingtonpost.com/neighbors.php?type=name&oldest=1&lname=carey&fname=drew&search=Search|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} On the September 26, 2008, episode of ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]'', Carey defined "libertarian" to host [[Craig Ferguson]] as "a [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] who still [[Recreational drug use|gets high]]."{{cite news |last=O'Hare |first=Kate |title=AMC explores what it means to be Republican in Hollywood |work=[[San Diego Union-Tribune]] |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040914/news_lz1c14hollywd.html |date=September 14, 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EAJvJoA?url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040914/news_lz1c14hollywd.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016]], he supported [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] presidential candidate [[Gary Johnson presidential campaign, 2016|Gary Johnson]] in his run for office,{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/07/24/drew-carey-wants-libertarian-gary-johnson-as-president|title=Drew Carey Wants Libertarian Gary Johnson As President|first=Matt|last=Wilstein|date=24 July 2016|website=The Daily Beast}} and was made an Honorary Chair of the campaign for California.https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ct8j1fBVIAEkKV3.jpg:large {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161030164329/https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ct8j1fBVIAEkKV3.jpg%3Alarge |date=2016-10-30 }} Carey has spoken about his various political beliefs in several interviews, and in 1998, he led a "smoke-in" in defiance of California's newly passed [[smoking ban|no-smoking ordinance]] inside bars and restaurants.{{Cite news|last=Hunt|first=Dennis|work=[[USA Today]]|title=Puffers' protest: Cigar, cigarette, Drew Carey|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/28327394.html?dids=28327394:28327394&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+01%2C+1998&author=Dennis+Hunt&pub=USA+TODAY&desc=Puffers%27+protest%3A+Cigar%2C+cigarette%2C+Drew+Carey&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=April 1, 1998|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} Carey has hosted a series of mini-documentaries called ''The Drew Carey Project'' on Reason.tv,{{Cite news |last=McCoy |first=Adrian |title=Cybertainment: Busy Drew Carey adds online documentaries to schedule |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07299/828758-370.stm |date=October 26, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EAWYCn1?url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07299/828758-370.stm |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} an online project of [[Reason Foundation]], a libertarian-oriented nonprofit [[think tank]] (for which Carey sits as a member of the board of trustees{{Cite web|url = http://reason.org/about/faq/#q10|title = Frequently Asked Questions|accessdate = 10 August 2013|publisher = [[Reason Foundation]]}}). The first episode, "Gridlock", addresses private highway ownership and was released on October 15, 2007. Other episodes discuss topics such as [[eminent domain]], urban traffic congestion, and [[medical marijuana]]. ===Sports involvement=== Carey is a devoted fan of the [[United States men's national soccer team|U.S. National Soccer Team]], [[Cleveland Browns]], [[Cleveland Cavaliers]], [[Cleveland Indians]], and the [[Columbus Blue Jackets]]. In 1999, Carey was part of the pregame ceremonies at the first game of the return of the [[Cleveland Browns]], televised on [[ESPN]]. Carey attended the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in Germany and the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] in South Africa. Carey is a minority owner of the [[Seattle Sounders FC]], who began play in [[Major League Soccer]] on March 19, 2009, and won the 2016 MLS Cup. Carey is a fan of [[FC Barcelona]] and of the Scottish team [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]].{{Cite news |publisher=BBC News |title=Xbox turns star into Rangers fan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/4396443.stm |date=March 31, 2005 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EAZDMQW?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/4396443.stm |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2006, he was a season ticketholder for the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]].{{cite web |work=FIFA.Yahoo.com |title=You can't stop a train |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/germany2006/news/newsid=27067.html |date=June 21, 2006 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EAcQRLn?url=http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/germany2006/news/newsid=27067.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all |access-date=December 3, 2017 }} [[File:Drewcarey-brownsdedication.jpg|thumb|Carey preparing for a TV broadcast at the dedication of [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], September 1999]] Carey has shown his support for the Indians by throwing the first pitch at an August 12, 2006, game against the [[Kansas City Royals]]. He was rewarded by the Cleveland Indians for being "the greatest Indians fan alive" with a personal [[bobblehead doll]] made in his likeness that was given to fans. Carey responded to his bobblehead likeness by saying "Bobblehead Day, for me, is as big as getting a star in the Hollywood Walk of Fame."{{cite web|work=MLB.com|title=Indians 2006 Photo Gallery|url=http://www.mlb.com/cle/photogallery/year_2006/month_08/day_13/cf1608249.html|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} In 2001, Carey was the first television actor to enter [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation's]] 30-man "[[Royal Rumble (2001)|Royal Rumble]]" match, which he did to promote an improv comedy [[pay-per-view]] at the time. He appeared in a few backstage segments before his brief participation in the match. Upon entering the ring, Carey stood unopposed for more than half a minute, but after the next entrant, [[Kane (wrestler)|Kane]], refused a monetary bribe, Carey eliminated himself from the match by jumping over the top rope and retreating from ringside.{{cite news|last=Tyra|first=Ty|work=[[The Tennessean]]|title=Test your Rumble knowledge|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/tennessean/access/1835600861.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+19%2C+2002&author=&pub=The+Tennessean&desc=Test+your+Rumble+knowledge&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=January 19, 2002|accessdate=July 16, 2011}} On April 2, 2011, Carey was inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] by Kane.{{cite news |last=Fishman |first=Scott |title=Show stops for HBK during WWE Hall of Fame ceremony |work=[[The Miami Herald]] |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/04/03/2148288/show-stops-for-hbk-during-wwe.html |date=April 3, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Fr2JHxp?url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/04/03/2148288/show-stops-for-hbk-during-wwe.html |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Carey competed against five other celebrities in the first celebrity edition of the 2003 [[World Poker Tour]]. He placed fifth, beating out only actor [[Jack Black]]. Carey won $2,000 for his charity.{{cite web |publisher=[[World Poker Tour]] |title=Hollywood Home Game 1 |url=http://www.worldpokertour.com/Shared/Tournaments/Seasons/WPT_Specials/Hollywood_Home_Game_I.aspx |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EB6bxHw?url=http://www.worldpokertour.com/Shared/Tournaments/Seasons/WPT_Specials/Hollywood_Home_Game_I.aspx |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On May 15, 2011, Carey completed the "Marine Corps Historic Half Marathon" in 1:57:02; then, on September 4, 2011, he improved to complete the Disneyland Half Marathon in 1:50:46. And on October 30, 2011, he finished the Marine Corps Marathon with a [[Transponder timing|chip time]] of 4:37:11, placing 10,149th out of 20,940. ===Philanthropy=== [[File:DrewCareyPhotoSept01.jpg|alt=Carey smiling broadly, minus his usual glasses and in casual clothes with a green contest entry top. He is holding a camera with a long lens.|thumb|upright|Carey at the World Cup Fest in [[Kaiserslautern, Germany]], in June 2006, while filming ''Drew Carey's Sporting Adventures'']] Carey is a supporter of libraries, crediting them for beginning his successful comedy career. On May 2, 2000, in a celebrity edition of ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire (US game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire]]'', he selected the Ohio Library Foundation to receive his $500,000 winnings.{{Cite news |last=Bauder |first=David |publisher=[[CBS News]] |title=Fat Figures for Celebrity Millionaire |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/05/04/entertainment/main191844.shtml |date=May 4, 2000 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EB9pDOV?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/05/04/entertainment/main191844.shtml |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He later went on to win an additional $32,000 on the second celebrity ''Millionaire'', making him one of the biggest winning contestants on ''Millionaire'' who did not win the top prize. Carey also has played on the World Poker Tour in the Hollywood Home games for the [[Cleveland Public Library]] charity.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldpokertour.com/Shared/Players/Bios/D/Drew_Carey.aspx |publisher=[[World Poker Tour]] |title=Players-Drew Carey |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EBCHdxR?url=http://www.worldpokertour.com/Shared/Players/Bios/D/Drew_Carey.aspx |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In June 2007, Carey offered to donate up to $100,000 (in $10,000 increments) to the Mooch Myernick Memorial Fund if anybody could beat him at the video game [[FIFA 07|FIFA Soccer 07]] for the [[Xbox 360]]. He dared five players from both the U.S. Men's and Women's National Teams to compete against him.{{cite news |last=Kohler |first=Chris |title=Drew Carey Challenges Footballers to FIFA, For Charity |publisher=[[Wired News]] |url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2007/05/drew_carey_chal/ |date=May 30, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Fp8jhOW?url=http://www.wired.com/gamelife/2007/05/drew_carey_chal/ |archivedate=July 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Carey ended up donating $100,000, plus $60,000 for losing two games out of the six games he played.{{cite news|last=Canales |first=Andrea |title=Myernick/Carey Event a Success |url=http://www.chicagolandsoccernews.com/teams/usa2.php?article_id=2570 |publisher=Chicagoland Soccer News |date=June 6, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003110506/http://www.chicagolandsoccernews.com/teams/usa2.php?article_id=2570 |archivedate=October 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In October 2009, Carey made a bid of $25,000 in a charity auction for the @drew [[Twitter]] account. He later increased his offer to $100,000 if the number of followers of his account @DrewFromTV reached 100,000 by the end of the auction.{{Cite news |last=Moore |first=Matthew |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/6258857/Drew-Carey-bids-100000-for-drew-Twitter-account-in-cancer-auction.html |title=Drew Carey bids $100,000 for @drew Twitter account in cancer auction |date=October 4, 2009 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EBFWwgT?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/6258857/Drew-Carey-bids-100000-for-drew-Twitter-account-in-cancer-auction.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df= }} In an interview with CBS News, he said he would instead donate $1 million to the charity [[Lance Armstrong Foundation|Livestrong Foundation]] if his follower count reached one million by December 31, 2009.{{cite news |last=Lazar |first=Shira |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2009/10/07/onthescene/entry5368580.shtml |title=Exclusive: Drew Carey Ups The Ante To $1 Million |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=October 7, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EBRsAKZ?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504464_162-5368580-504464.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Another of Carey's offers to contribute in helping others came in September 2014 when he promised $10,000 to help find the perpetrators of a faked "ice bucket challenge" involving an autistic 14-year-old Ohio boy who, instead of being doused in ice cubes and water, received a shower of feces, urine, tobacco spit, and cigarette butts.{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-drew-carey-als-ice-bucket-challenge-reward-ohio-20140907-story.html |title=Drew Carey offers $10,000 reward after alleged prank on autistic boy |last=Hamedy |first=Saba |date=September 7, 2014 |website=LATimes.com |publisher=Tribune Publishing |access-date=December 18, 2016 |quote=}} Shortly thereafter, celebrities [[Donnie Wahlberg]], [[Jenny McCarthy]] and [[Montel Williams]] matched Carey's offer.{{cite web |url=https://www.salon.com/2014/09/09/drew_carey_and_jenny_mccarthys_misguided_mission/ |title=Vigilante justice on the Internet: Drew Carey and Jenny McCarthy's dumb stunt |last=Williams |first=Mary Elizabeth |date=September 9, 2014 |website=Salon |publisher=Salon Media Group, Inc. |access-date=December 18, 2016 |quote=}} ==Photography== Carey can sometimes be seen on the sidelines of U.S. National Team soccer games as a press photographer.{{Cite news |last=Deitsch |first=Richard |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |title=Q&A: Drew Carey |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/richard_deitsch/06/14/drew.carey/index.html |date=June 14, 2005 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60EBXFqcS?url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/richard_deitsch/06/14/drew.carey/index.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} His images are sold via wire services under the pseudonym ''Brooks Parkenridge''. He was at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in the summer of 2006, for his television show ''Drew Carey's Sporting Adventures''. ==Filmography== Carey has starred in only a few television shows and films, but has made numerous guest-star appearances in a variety of sitcoms and comedy shows. ===Television=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !
